description:
In highly problematic ways Asian Medical Systems are colonial, Orientalist
constructs that have been heavily influenced by nationalism and the
modernity of religion. It is common to speak of Ayurveda (“Indian”
medicine), Unani (Greek/Arabic/”Islamic” medicine), Traditional Chinese
Medicine and Tibetan Buddhist Medicine as though these are timeless, authentic, self‐contained traditions. Drawing on a range of contemporary
theoretical insights in anthropology and history this course examines the way
in which forms of “medical” knowledge and embodied practice in Asia are
shaped by the cultural dynamics of pre‐colonial, colonial and post‐colonial
globalization.
title: Asian Medicine, the Body and Globalization
